headline: ‘Shortness of breath remains most frequent complication among COVID-19 survivors’
summarized_story:
Angela OnwuzooA systematic review of 45 studies on COVID-19 survivors has revealed that many of them even after recovery, still frequently experience health challenges such as shortness of breath, fatigue and sleep disorders.
In the systematic review, the authors used data from cohort studies to examine the frequency, variety, and severity of persistent symptoms among individuals with previous COVID-19 infection and found out that shortness of breath remained the most frequent.
Nasserie and colleagues in the review involving 45 studies including 9,751 participants with COVID-19 found that COVID-19 symptoms usually persisted beyond the acute phase of infection, with implications for health-associated functioning and quality of life.
“Persistent symptoms were defined as those persisting for at least 60 days after diagnosis, symptom onset, or hospitalisation or at least 30 days after recovery from the acute illness or hospital discharge.
Continuing, the authors noted, “The most frequently reported persistent symptoms were fatigue and shortness of breath, both of which can be debilitating.

headline: Kanu drags Nigeria, Kenya to African Commission on Human and Peoples Rights
summarized_story:

headline: Anthony Stimler, former Glencore trader, pleads guilty over oil bribery scheme in Nigeria
summarized_story:
Anthony Stimler, a former UK-based trader for Glencore Plc, has pleaded guilty to participating in an international scheme to bribe officials in Nigeria to win favourable contracts from the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC).
Court papers also identified seven alleged co-conspirators from several countries in the bribery scheme, including UK, Nigeria, Mexico, Spain and Israel in a deal that ran from 2007 to 2018.
In November 2017, NNPC sought buyers from oil traders willing to pay $3.5 to $5 billion and get its value in crude oil between five and seven years.
Glencore emerged as one of the oil traders selected to lift Nigeria’s crude oil under various contracts, such as the crude oil term deal and the direct sale direct purchase scheme.
In 2018, NNPC acknowledged receipt of $94.279 million, about N28.85 billion, for a total of 1.9 million barrels of Nigerian crude oil.

headline: The Next Wave: Scale is hard to find in Africa
summarized_story:
The top 4% No standard definitions exist for what scale is for fintech in Africa.

Mr James Ojomo, an expert in drug abuse, says many of the major towns including Kano, Kaduna, Abuja and Lagos are veritable grounds for drug abusers.
“ For some time, the country was not serious in waging war against drug abuse, as we were treating it with kid grooves.

headline: Former UK-based trader pleads guilty in oil bribery scheme involving Nigerian officials, NNPC
summarized_story:
ADVERTISEMENTA former United Kingdom-based trader for Glencore Plc, Anthony Stimler, on Monday pleaded guilty over what prosecutors in the United States described as his role in a scheme to bribe officials in Nigeria in exchange for favourable contracts from the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation, NNPC.
“The conduct described in the plea is unacceptable and has no place in Glencore,” the company said.
Earlier in March, former Glencore oil trader Emilio Jose Heredia Collado pleaded guilty in San Francisco to manipulating a key oil price benchmark.
U.K. and Swiss authorities have also been examining possible corruption involving Glencore, and various governments have investigated other large oil traders.
The spokesperson of Nigeria’s state-owned oil company, NNPC, Kennie Obateru, did not return a phone call as of press time Tuesday morning.

headline: Livestock Feeds reports N7bn as turnover in Q2 2021
summarized_story:
Adebayo ObajemuLivestock Feeds on Monday published its Second Quarter result for the period ended 30 June 2021 on the website of the Nigerian Exchange Group.
Livestock Feeds reported a turnover of N7 billion, up by 42.32% from N4.92 billion reported the previous year.
Profit after tax grew by 258.21% to N337.921 million from N94.337 million reported in Q2 2020.
Earnings per share (EPS) of the company increased significantly to 11 kobo from the EPS of 3 kobo achieved the previous year.
At the share price of N2.16, the P.E ratio of Livestock Feeds stands at 19.18x with earnings yield of 5.21

headline: FGN July bonds oversubscribed by 90.74%- DMO
summarized_story:
Adebayo ObajemuThe Debt Management Office has disclosed that the Federal Government(FGN) bonds worth N150bn for July which were auctioned on Monday were oversubscribed by 90.74%.
The total subscription received from investors for the bonds was N286.11bn, comprising of N56.41bn for 13.98 per cent FGN February 2028 bonds, N73.44bn for 12.4 per cent FGN March 2036 bonds, and N156.26bn for 12.98 per cent FGN March 2050 bonds.
This implies N136.11 billion above the offered amount of N150 billion.
According to DMO: “Successful bids for the 13.98% FGN bond due in February 2028; 12.4% FGN bond due in March 2036 and 12.98% Federal government bond due in March 2050 were allotted at the marginal rates of 12.35 per cent, 13.15 per cent and 13.25 per cent respectively”.
He also went further to say: “However, the original coupon rates of 13.98% for the 13.98% FGN FEB 2028, 12.40% for the 12.40% FGN MAR 2036 and 12.98% for the 12.98% FGN MAR 2050 will be maintained.

headline: JUST-IN: 4 More Abducted Bethel School Students Regain Freedom
summarized_story:
Less than 24 hours after the release of the 28 students of Bethel Baptist High School by their abductors on Sunday July 25, 2021, four additional students have been recovered on Monday, leaving 83 of the students still in captivity.
Pastor Adebayo Oladeji, public relations officer (PRO) of the FCT Baptist Conference, told LEADERAHIP through short message via WhatsApp late Monday night.
According to him, “the students escaped from the camp of the bandits last night (Sunday).
With the 6 that were earlier rescued, we now have 38 students out of the hands of the bandits from the 121 students kidnapped.
Meanwhile, the President, Kaduna Baptist Conference and proprietor of the Bethel Baptist High School, Rev Ishaya Adamu Jangado, who commended all the parents and well-wishers for their prayers and perseverance, also expressed optimism that the remaining students will be released.

headline: Be Accountable, Governor Abiodun Tells New LG Chairmen
summarized_story:
Ogun State governor, Prince Dapo Abiodun on Monday, charged the newly elected council chairmen in the state to be accountable to the people at the grassroots that voted them to power, saying they must hold in sanctity, the rule of law during the period they will be piloting the affairs of their respective council areas.
The governor also admonished the new council bosses to see their assumption of office as a means of enthroning a new vista of development to the people at the grassroots.
“You must be inclusive; you must be transparent; you must be accountable; you must be fair; you must be just; you must be equitable; you must obey the rule of law; you must provide good governance; you must be judicious.
Above all you cannot afford to turn yourselves to “Mr or Mrs I know it all”.
“In addition, you must also appreciate the fact that your victory at the polls is multi-dimensional.

headline: Labour, CSOs launch campaign for transformative governance
summarized_story:
Labour and Pro-Labour Civil Society Organisations, CSOs, yesterday launched a Campaign for Transformative Governance to end bad governance, corruption, and human insecurity.
The campaign is joint labour and pro-labour CSOs advocacy and platform to influence radical changes in government policies, processes and institutions at all levels towards achieving transformative governance.
The pro-labour CSOs include the Trade Union Congress, TUC, Amalgamated Union of Public Corporation Civil Service and Recreational Service Employees, AUPCTRE, Federation of Informal Workers of Nigeria, FIWON.
According to the statement, ‘‘it is unacceptable that a country with enormous resources would be ranked among the poorest in the world.
The facts and figures paint a very grim picture.’’The three thematic areas of the campaign are ensuring accessible and effective public service delivery, political education of citizens for transformative governance, and promoting human security as a panacea to the endemic insecurity and ravaging poverty in the country.

headline: Nigeria Records 213 More COVID-19 Cases, Two New Deaths
summarized_story:
Nigeria has confirmed 213 new cases of coronavirus (COVID-19) in various parts of the country, said the Federal Government agency responsible for the control of disease outbreaks.
The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) disclosed this in its latest update on the outbreak, saying the new cases were reported in 12 states on Monday.
Of the cases, Lagos recorded an alarming number of infections – 157 – at a time when the whole country had reported low cases in previous months.
Of the confirmed cases, 164,798 cases have been discharged and 2,134 deaths have been recorded in all 36 states of the Federation and the Federal Capital Territory (FCT).
As Nigeria’s confirmed cases continue to rise with fears and panic from citizens, authorities have yet to officially declare a third wave of the pandemic.

summarized_story:
Four additional students kidnapped from Kaduna’s Bethel Baptist College have regained their freedom.

headline: Tanzania’s Opposition Leader Mbowe Charged With Terrorism
summarized_story:
The leader of Tanzania’s main opposition party has been charged with terrorism-related offences by a court in the East African country.
The charges against Chadema chairman Freeman Mbowe follows his arrest that drew international concern and criticism of the country’s new president.

Chadema said Mbowe had been charged in Kisutu court with terrorism crimes without his family or lawyers present.

headline: British High Commissioner to Nigeria Speaks on Global Education Summit and Keeping Nigerian Schools Safe

Laing spoke on how the summit will be an opportunity for world leaders to make five-year pledges to support GPE’s work to invest in education and improve access for girls in up to 90 countries and territories.

headline: Tropical Storm to Bring Rain, Wind, Waves to Northeast Japan
summarized_story:
An offshore tropical storm brought wind and rain to the Tokyo region and affected some Olympic events Tuesday as it headed toward northeastern Japan, where stormier conditions were forecast.
The Japan Meteorological Agency predicted Nepartak would bring heavy rains, strong winds and high waves to northeastern Japan in advance of its landfall around midday Wednesday north of the capital region.
The tropical storm had winds of 72 kilometers per hour (44.7 mph) around midday Tuesday off Chiba on Japan’s central-eastern coast, the agency said.
Some traffic disruptions are expected in the northern region.
At the Olympics, some surfing events planned for Wednesday were moved to Tuesday, but the storm gave the competitors big waves for their final day of competition.
